title: How to Make Homemade Salsa with Fresh Produce

steps.headline: Wash your cilantro thoroughly.
steps.description: Start by going through the cilantro and removing any limp/browning leaves, and removing large stems.

steps.headline: Gather some cold water in a large bowl and set it down in the sink.
Put the cilantro in th water and let it sit, but move your hands around in it, so as to clean out any dirt that might be clinging to the leaves.
Place in it a strainer and shake it to remove the water
Repeat the process twice more.
Either dry on a paper towel or just cut it while it's slightly wet.
Finely chop it until it is thin, but not too fine.
Wash the jalapenos off in the sink and place them on a cutting board.
Remove the stem and other end, then slice the jalapeno.
steps.description: Either remove or keep the seeds, but the seeds will give an extra spice. Use a nice, sharp knife, and cut it into quarters.

steps.headline: Peel and chop the white onion into sizable pieces for your food processor.
Halve it first, then lay it horizontally, cut side down on your board.
Chop it 2-3 times horizontally, then cut it vertically.
Do the same with the other half.
Peel the garlic cloves.
steps.description: Either chop them in half or leave them whole, depending on how strong your food processor is.

steps.headline: Blanch and peel tomatoes or open your can of fresh cut tomatoes.
steps.description: Chop them into halves or quarters, whichever you like, and set them aside.

steps.headline: Place cilantro, garlic, white onion, olive oil, and seeded Jalapeno pieces into Food Processor.
Pulse until smooth.
Add the fresh peeled tomatoes or cans of tomatoes into food processor.
Puree until smooth.
Add half-teaspoon of salt.
Finished.

text: Part 1: Prepping the Food Wash your cilantro thoroughly. Start by going through the cilantro and removing any limp/browning leaves, and removing large stems. Gather some cold water in a large bowl and set it down in the sink.  Put the cilantro in th water and let it sit, but move your hands around in it, so as to clean out any dirt that might be clinging to the leaves.  Place in it a strainer and shake it to remove the water  Repeat the process twice more.  Either dry on a paper towel or just cut it while it's slightly wet.  Finely chop it until it is thin, but not too fine.  Wash the jalapenos off in the sink and place them on a cutting board.  Remove the stem and other end, then slice the jalapeno. Either remove or keep the seeds, but the seeds will give an extra spice. Use a nice, sharp knife, and cut it into quarters. Peel and chop the white onion into sizable pieces for your food processor.  Halve it first, then lay it horizontally, cut side down on your board.  Chop it 2-3 times horizontally, then cut it vertically.  Do the same with the other half.  Peel the garlic cloves. Either chop them in half or leave them whole, depending on how strong your food processor is. Blanch and peel tomatoes or open your can of fresh cut tomatoes. Chop them into halves or quarters, whichever you like, and set them aside. Part 2: Putting it Together Place cilantro, garlic, white onion, olive oil, and seeded Jalapeno pieces into Food Processor.  Pulse until smooth.  Add the fresh peeled tomatoes or cans of tomatoes into food processor.  Puree until smooth.  Add half-teaspoon of salt.  Finished.
